Following oral administration, NTZ is absorbed in the intestine, where it is rapidly hydrolysed by plasma esterase into the active metabolite tizoxanide.
235 The mechanism of action of NTZ varies according to the pathogen. In relation to antiviral activity, NTZ blocks the maturation of the viral hemagglutinin at the post-translation stage in treatments against influenza. In treatments against HCV (hepatitis C), it activates protein kinase R (PKR), which leads to phosphorylation of the eukaryotic initiation factor-2Î± thereby preventing translation.
